title: Curbar Edge Circular Walk Route

images.title: Alan Fleming / Curbar Edge, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Along Curbar Edge towards Froggatt on a clear spring day. The edge is a great place for wildlife with birds including heron, barn owl, buzzard and kestrel to look out for. You can also see deer rutting from September to November.

images.title: Chris Wimbush / Curbar Edge, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Curbar Edge view on a winter's day.

images.title: Lynne Kirton / On top of Curbar Edge, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: On top of Curbar Edge.The gritstone escarpment commands fine views across the Derwent valley

images.title: Chris Wimbush / Curbar Edge, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The millstone grit and heather are very typical of this area. Baslow Edge at the other side of Curbar Gap can be seen in the distance.

images.title: Path towards a well concealed car park by Andrew Hill, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path towards a well concealed car park

images.title: Curbar Edge cattle by Andrew Hill, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cattle on the rocks.

images.title: Lynne Kirton / Curbar Edge and the Derwent valley
images.caption: The Edge and the Derwent valley in autumn. It is a very popular area for rock climbing and walking.

description: This circular walk takes you along the spectacular Curbar Edge in the Peak District. From the elevated position on Curbar Edge there are magnificent views over the Eastern Moors of the Peak District. The area is also covered with interesting rock formations. Look out for red deer on the moors and birdlife such as the Ring Ouzel, in the air. The walk starts from the Curbar Gap Car Park and soon picks up the footpath to take you along the gritsone escarpment of Curbar Edge. You'll pass unusual rock stacks and some woodland trails with fabulous views towards Big Moor and White Edge. It is a fairly easy walk without too much strenuous climbing. If you would  like to extend your walk then the wonderful, National Trust owned Longshaw Estate is a good option. It is located a couple of miles to the north and consists of miles of walking and cycling paths taking you through ancient woods, parkland and heather moorland. On the way you will pass Froggatt Edge which has some nice birch woodland and more great views. Curbar Edge is located just a few miles south west of Sheffield. The nearby village of Calver is also well worth a visit with its historic cotton mill and the River Derwent. You could pick up the Derwent Valley Heritage Way here and enjoy a riverside walk. A couple of miles to the south east you will find Birchen Edge. It's another geologically fascinating area with fine views over the Derwent Valley. The walk can also be started from the nearby village of Baslow if you prefer.
